block.p: Bush Gives Dire Threat To Iraq on Disarmament President Bush threatened Saddam Hussein in dire terms, if he did not fully disclose Iraq's inventory of weapons by the United Nations' deadline of Dec. 8. Mr. Bush called on NATO to re-create itself as a leaner and swifter military force to take on the new threat of terrorism -- including, Mr. Hussein.

The governments of Britain, Australia, Denmark and several other nations are strongly considering formal requests from the United States to join a military coalition against Iraq if weapons inspections fail. More than 50 nations have been contacted by American diplomats.

Israeli Soldiers Kill Teenager Israeli soldiers shot and killed a second Palestinian teenager in the West Bank city of Tulkarm. The army said that in each case, the boys had been throwing gasoline bombs, but Palestinian witnesses said they only had stones.

Afghans to Get Customs Help The Treasury Department will send customs officials to assess the chaotic system at Afghanistan's main border crossings in an effort to help the country gain control of customs revenues.

Musharraf Firmly on Top General Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan addressed the nation as he prepared to turn his executive powers over to a new prime minister. As he spoke of reforms, it was clear that he will remain at the helm. He will continue as both president and as army chief of staff.

Turkey Courts European Union The leader of Turkey's new governing party has promised to change laws and amend the Constitution, to root out graft and to make concessions on Cyprus, in order to join the European Union.
Turkey's broadcasting authority authorized state radio and television to air limited programs in the once-banned Kurdish language, a step toward meeting European Union membership requirements.

Deferring to Jiang in China In his secret acceptance speech after being appointed China's Communist Party chief, Hu Jintao pledged that on important matters he would consult with his predecessor, Jiang Zemin. That the speech is being used to ensure Mr. Jiang's special status as ''party sage'' is widely known among officials.

U.S. Acquittal Angers Korea A United States Army sergeant was acquitted in an American military court of criminal negligence in the deaths of two South Korean girls who were crushed by an armored vehicle. The case has sparked the largest anti-American rallies in South Korea in years.

Arrests in Russian Murder Six men have been arrested in Russia and charged with the murder of a member of Parliament who was shot four years ago. The murky investigation represents democratic transition in a country where assassination is a feature of politics and the law still struggles to find its way.

F.B.I. Officials Frustrated By Antiterror Performance According to internal memos and interviews senior F.B.I. officials have grown frustrated with the bureau's performance in the war on terrorism, and they are demanding that agents nationwide become more aggressive in hunting terrorists.

Drug Companies Talk Strategy Leaders of major drug companies, having spent some $30 million on Congressional elections, are devising ways to capitalize on their success by securing favorable new legislation and countering the pressure from lawmakers to lower the cost of prescription drugs.
Ruling on Sniper Suspect's Kin Federal immigration authorities have ordered Una James, the mother of Lee Malvo, the 17-year-old youth charged in the sniper shootings, deported to Jamaica.
Church Fights for Its Cemetery Members of St. John's Church in Bensenville, Ill. are fighting a $6.6 billion plan to expand the adjacent O'Hare International Airport onto the church's cemetery.

Airport Security Gets Ready The head of the Transportation Security Administration said airport security personnel would ''make common-sense judgments'' to avoid creating ''multihour lines'' during the busy holiday season.

Furor Over AmeriCorps Pledge A proposal to change the pledge taken by AmeriCorps members to include references to God and defending the Constitution has stirred an outcry among participants in the federally supported organization.

Vaccine Blocks Cervical Cancer Scientists have created the first vaccine that appears able to prevent cervical cancer, by making people immune to a sexually transmitted virus that causes many cases of the disease.

Grant for Energy Research Several big international companies, including the oil giant Exxon Mobil, said they would contribute $225 million over 10 years to Stanford University for research on ways to supply growing energy needs without worsening global warming.

Tobacco Money May Save City From Fiscal Crisis Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plans for pulling the city out of its fiscal crisis include borrowing $1.4 billion against expected payments from tobacco companies, and New York State lawmakers are considering similar moves to close its own vast deficit.

Teenagers File Obesity Suit Two young women are suing the McDonald's Corporation and the two Bronx restaurants they frequented for damages related to their obesity. A federal judge in Manhattan heard a motion to dismiss the case presented by lawyers for McDonald's, but has not yet ruled on it.

The High-Stress Headmaster The job of running a high-profile private school has become extraordinarily complex, with some leaders in the field arguing that its mix of curriculum development, public relations, fund-raising, conflict resolution, urban construction and interpersonal relationships with the board, the faculty, the alumni, the parents and the students is more suited to a chief executive than an educator.
James R. Hendrix A recipient of the Medal of Honor for single-handedly capturing 13 German soldiers and rescuing fellow G.I.'s during the Battle of the Bulge in World War II, he was 77.

Prosecutors Issue Subpoenas Prosecutors issued subpoenas to customers and former employees of Computer Associates, where investigators are examining whether executives inflated profits to reach a $1.1 billion payday that was tied to the price of shares.

United Union Agrees to Cuts The machinists' union at United agreed to $1.5 billion in concessions in an effort to help the airline avoid filing for bankruptcy protection. United now needs approval of its application for $1.8 billion in loan guarantees.

Plans for Venture in China Wang Yung-ching, Taiwan's wealthiest industrialist, plans to start a network of auto parts factories in China, where he expects his Formosa Plastics Group to assemble cars in partnership with General Motors.
Financier Folds as Pain Spreads The collapse of National Century Financial Enterprises has pushed some of the company's clients into bankruptcy and forced others to scramble for financing.
